climbs.name: Sweat Lodge
climbs.fa: Shane Willet, Paul Moore, Mark Nakada 1996

content.description: Awkward crux down low.  Fun roof moves above.

This route lies just right of Sweat Lodge and left of the chimney system that is Colorectal Surgery, on the right or West side of the cliff.  Start on an easy pillar trending up and right past 11 bolts.  There is an awkward move at the top of the pillar, cryptic moves get you past the seemingly blank headwall, and wild overhanging jugs to finish
content.location: Starts on easy pillar as above.......

content.description:
Just right of

Crescent Moon

, this route starts on an arete and changes aspects at mid height and ascends a clean face. The crux is near the top with some long reaches and pulls. My favorite warm up/cool down at Ruth Lake.

climbs.name: Frolic
climbs.fa: T. Kemple Sr and J. Frohlich

content.description: Start up easy pillar. When the rock turns pink, the climbing gets really good!
content.location: Follow directions to Last Stand. This route is on far right, or West side of cliff, just past chimney system with offwidth size crack

content.description:
This climb is located just right of

Peyote Trip

and shares its anchors. Climb up a broken face past a couple of bolts to ever increasing difficulty on a nice arete with a finger crack on its left side. Pull onto a ledge and climb the short face above past two more bolts. The crux is the middle of the route and is pretty sustained.
content.protection:
8 bolts plus shared 2 bolt anchor of

Peyote Trip

.

content.description:
You will find interesting climbing up a wide crack/narrow chimney.

Crux is a small overhang. Off-width skills not required.Lichen, moss and loose blocks add spice to the 5.8 grade. (I rated it a "bomb," due to the loose blocks.) Construct your anchor with two double length runners (around small trees) and a 0.75 Camalot in a shallow hole. To the West of this crack is a low angle gully which serves as the descent route. Welcome to the real world.
content.protection:
No bolts, but the crack allows for good protection.

Trees at top provide anchors. A .75 camalot can also be used. (Feel free to add a bolt anchor if there is any evidence that the trees are being damaged or do not provide an adequate anchor.)

Cams and nuts provide excellent protection on this route. Bring one 4-5 inch cam for the wide section.

Be certain your belayer stands to the side, so that you do not crush their skull with a loose block.
content.location: This pitch is a crack/chimney located at the far West (ie climber's right) of the Last Stand Wall. Descent: walk down the easy gully West of the climb.

content.description:
This is the second route on the right side of the

Last Stand Wall

. Easy climbing up into a right facing dihedral with a roof at the top. The crux is pulling the roof and is not very obvious. Don't pump out trying to unlock the sequence and then cruise the awesome face and roofs above. One of my favorites.

First route on the left side of the

Last Stand Wall

. This route faces more easterly than the rest of the routes on the wall and climbs a clean slab. A bulge at mid height provides the crux.

Sharing the same great start with

The Last Stand

,

Fist Full of Scalps

takes a turn towards the hard stuff!

Climb past three or four bolts on solid

Uinta Quartzite

heading straight up the quickly steepening line. Take advantage of a rest before the bulge and get fired up.  Move into the crux using what you can and explode onto the face continuing to hold your intensity. Micro edge feet, thin crimpy holds, and an intense clip define this routes crux. Figure out what you can while you can and move with confidence towards the chains.
content.protection: Draws for eight bolts plus a chain anchor.
content.location:
Fist Full of Scalps

climbs the direct dead center of the

Last Stand Wall

attacking the middle shield of rock.

FFOS

shares the start with

The Last Stand

and is just left of

Scalp Fest
